A telecommunications director generally is responsible for the planning and design of an organization’s telecommunication system which is comprised of voice services, data networks, and communication systems. The director usually takes into account present, as well as projected, volume of an organization’s communications. She then considers the efficiency and sufficiency of the present telecommunications system and makes recommendations for change.

Telecommunication managers have strong project management skills. When a bank wants to install a computer network that works across all its branches, for example, managers coordinate the purchase, installation and testing of equipment and systems, and ensure the projected is completed on time and on budget. The work of telecommunication managers goes beyond ensuring the efficiency of an organization’s telecommunication infrastructure.

A telecommunications network is a collection of terminal nodes, links are connected so as to enable telecommunication between the terminals. Computer networks can range from a local network area to a wide area network. The difference between the types of networks is the size. These types of computer networks work at certain speeds, also known as broadband. The Internet network connects computers worldwide.

COMPENSATION AND BENEFITS The salary for the Deputy Director, Telecommunications Division, is open and negotiable depending upon the skills and qualifications of the successful candidate. The Deputy Director is a Governor’s Office appointee. The Deputy Director receives direction from the Director of the Department of General Services, and operationally reports through the Department’s Chief Deputy Director. The Deputy Director’s office is located in Sacramento, California.
